Award.AwardTitle: RCN: An International Arabidopsis Informatics Consortium

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
-------------------------

The model plant Arabidopsis thaliana plays a unique and essential role as the reference organism for all seed plant species. This project will establish a Research Coordination Network that will lead to the development of informatics tools and resources for Arabidopsis in particular and for plant biology in general. It will be an open network that aims to draw in a broad cross-section of the US and international Arabidopsis communities. Arabidopsis research is at a critical junction; a broad range of new data types are becoming available, and the community?s ability to address important questions depends on the integration, visualization and analysis of these data. Diverse research groups are inventing new informatics approaches and thus the community needs a mechanism by which to identify, explore, promote, and enhance these resources. This project will catalyze a radical change in the way in which US and international researchers coordinate data generation, analysis and visualization. This project has the following goals: 1) The development of standards for Arabidopsis data deposition and display, 2) Development of a plan to develop Arabidopsis informatics tools and resources for the US and international communities, 3) Establishment of an International Arabidopsis Informatics Consortium that will build upon the activities and resources that will be generated in this project, 4) Establishment of a website as a resource for interested scientists and the general public.

Broader Impacts: Through the coordination of Arabidopsis informatics efforts, this project will advance plant biology, create novel opportunities for research and education, and lead to the establishment and growth of an International Arabidopsis Informatics Consortium. The problems that the Arabidopsis community is facing today will also challenge other communities, and this type of coordinated international approach to leveraging informatics resources across borders should provide an example (and resources) for such communities. Experiences learned from this application will have a broad impact across biology, particularly for crop plants for which a similar expansion in data is occurring and which often can build on efforts pioneered in Arabidopsis. The resources developed in this project will be widely and freely available and will be useful for students and researchers at educational institutions of all sizes, for industry, and for the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arabidopsis thaliana, often referred to simply as "Arabidopsis", is a small flowering plant that is broadly used as a model organism in plant biology research and education. Arabidopsis is a member of the Brassicaceae family which includes well-known members cabbage and radish. While Arabidopsis itself is not a major crop, it has significant important advantages for basic plant biology research, e.g. in enabling scientists to understand how plants develop and thrive, including under stress conditions like drought or heat. Notably, Arabidopsis was the first plant to have its genome fully sequenced, in the year 2000, and those sequence data have underpinned many valuable studies. The knowledge gained through studying Arabidopsis has advanced our understanding of important plant species, such as corn and soybean, which contributes to food security and alleviating hunger and malnutrition. Interestingly, once the human genome was sequenced, it became apparent that a majority of human genes suspected to play a role in human diseases were also present in Arabidopsis. Thus, Arabidopsis has been used to study and analyze genes and biological processes that are vital in addressing human health.

The Arabidopsis community, and other communities that use Arabidopsis resources, rely on publicly‚Äêshared resources. Valuable resources accessed by researchers include genome sequence data and newer resources, with data and tools that are useful for a wide variety of research topics. Many of these resources have been generated by groups around the globe, and at an increasing rate due to technological advances and associated reductions in costs. Notably, key Arabidopsis genome datasets, useful to many plant scientists, had been housed within TAIR, an online resource; however, TAIR funding was set to expire around 2012 to 2013. Loss of TAIR and the genome data it managed would significantly impede future biological research. In response, Arabidopsis community conversations about the expected loss of TAIR, as well as other key challenges, led to the formation, in 2011, of the International Arabidopsis Informatics Consortium (IAIC). The IAIC was funded through this NSF Research Coordination Network (RCN) award to bring together a diverse set of plant scientists, computational experts, and bioinformaticians to discuss key challenges faced by the Arabidopsis and plant sciences communities. Initial questions included: Arabidopsis informatics needs are growing quickly, with new data types and a rapidly increasing rate of data generation. How to consolidate and integrate these data? Individual researchers are devising new data handling and visualization tools that have broad utility. How to make these widely available? The Arabidopsis community is global, yet most of the current informatics support is funded on a national level. How to leverage funding across borders? In sum, the question was to determine what would be the best way to internationalize Arabidopsis informatics efforts, integrate new tools, maintain long-term stability, and address the needs of users. Simultaneously, it was a priority to engage with researchers, students, and the public through approaches including a webpage, workshops, conference sessions, training opportunities, and publications.

The most significant project outcome was the collaborative development of the Araport informatics resource, conceived through a project-funded "Design Workshop" that included dozens of computational, bioinformatics, and plant biology experts. The intent was that Araport would serve as a "hub" for Arabidopsis resources, including important genome data, and link with resources developed by scientists around the world. This sharing of workload, expertise, innovation, and financial commitment had the goal to ensure that Araport would remain sustainable, and promote creativity and interaction. The IAIC award enabled members to collaboratively develop a vision for Araport's design, as well as assemble a team of experts to secure the resources necessary to build Araport.

Additional goals were to promote inter-disciplinary interactions (e.g. between "wet-lab" plant scientists and "dry-lab" informaticians and computational experts), strengthen international collaborations, provide training and professional development opportunities for early career scientists, and share information and outcomes. We achieved these goals through workshops, conferences, and funding support provided to invited speakers, meeting participants, and early career researchers. Specifically, the project directly convened three workshops, published three scientific articles, and organized or spoke at 13 conferences to disseminate information about the project, develop collaborations, and engage in discussions. In support of our goal to strengthen collaborations with other groups, the IAIC collaborated with another network/RCN to combine resources and enable more scientists to engage in our mutual activities. The two RCN projects collaborated on three workshops focused on ?bioinformatics and computational skills needed by plant scientists of the 21st century?, ?emerging genomics technologies?, and 'computational and genomics techniques'; and two international conference sessions: ?quantitative and computational biology? and ?emerging genomics technologies'. Finally, and perhaps of broadest impact to the plant sciences, this project provided funding support to approximately 100 early career researchers, including graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and junior faculty.
